project.name: wpapi
project.description: A client for interacting with the WordPress REST API

WP.name: WP
WP.description: A WP REST API client for Node.js

WPRequest.name: WPRequest
WPRequest.description: WPRequest is the base API request object constructor

filters.name: filters
filters.description:
Filter methods that can be mixed in to a request constructor's prototype to
allow that request to take advantage of the `?filter[]=` aliases for WP_Query
parameters for collection endpoints. These are most relevant to posts, pages
and CPTs.

autodiscovery.name: autodiscovery
autodiscovery.description:
Utility methods used to query a site in order to discover its available
API endpoints

parseRouteString.name: parseRouteString
parseRouteString.description: Take a WP route string (with PCRE named capture groups), such as

WPRequest.name: WPRequest
WPRequest.description: WPRequest is the base API request object constructor

params.name: options
params.description: A hash of options for the WPRequest instance

props.name: endpoint
props.description: The endpoint URI for the invoking WP instance

props.name: username
props.description: A username for authenticating API requests

props.name: password
props.description: A password for authenticating API requests

wp.name: wp
wp.description:
Create and return a handler for an arbitrary WP REST API endpoint.

The first two parameters mirror `register_rest_route` in the REST API
codebase:

params.name: namespace
params.description: A namespace string, e.g. 'myplugin/v1'

params.name: restBase
params.description: A REST route string, e.g. '/author/(?P<id>\d+)'

params.name: options
params.description: An (optional) options object

props.name: mixins
props.description: A hash of functions to apply as mixins

props.name: methods
props.description: An array of methods to whitelist (on the leaf node only)

return.description:
An endpoint handler factory function for the
specified route

WP.name: WP
WP.description: The base constructor for the WP API service

params.name: options
params.description: An options hash to configure the instance

props.name: endpoint
props.description: The URI for a WP-API endpoint

props.name: routes
props.description:
A dictionary of API routes with which to
                                   bootstrap the WP instance: the instance will
                                   be initialized with default routes only
                                   if this property is omitted

classitems.description: Helper method to request yes/no confirmation from the user, with some

return.description:
A promise that will resolve with a boolean true/false
indicating whether assent was given

classitems.description:
Get the list of files in a directory, either as a list of file and subdir
names or a list of absolute file system paths

params.name: inputDir
params.description: The file system path to the directory to read

return.description: A promise to the string array of file names

classitems.description:
Spawn a shell command, pipe its output to the parent process's stdio, and
return a promise that will resolve or reject when the subprocess completes

params.name: commandStr
params.description: A string containing a shell command to run

params.name: otherArgs
params.description:
Array of additional string arguments, so that
quoted arguments with spaces like github commit messages will not be broken

return.description:
A promise that will resolve if the command executes
successfully or reject if it errors

classitems.description:
Helper function that takes in an array of functions that return promises,
then executes those functions sequentially to execute each action

params.name: arrOfFnsReturningPromises
params.description: An array of functions

return.description:
A promise that will resolve once all the promises
returned by that function successfully complete

classitems.description: Configuration options for the request such as the endpoint for the invoking WP instance
classitems.name: _options

classitems.description:
A hash of query parameters
This is used to store the values for supported query parameters like ?_embed
classitems.name: _params

classitems.description:
Methods supported by this API request instance:
Individual endpoint handlers specify their own subset of supported methods
classitems.name: _supportedMethods

classitems.description:
A hash of values to assemble into the API request path
(This will be overwritten by each specific endpoint handler constructor)
classitems.name: _path

classitems.description:
Submit the provided superagent request object, invoke a callback (if it was
provided), and return a promise to the response from the HTTP request.

params.name: request
params.description: A superagent request object

params.name: callback
params.description: A callback function (optional)

params.name: transform
params.description: A function to transform the result data

return.description: A promise to the superagent request

classitems.description:
Return the body of the request, augmented with pagination information if the
result is a paged collection.
classitems.name: returnBody

params.name: result
params.description: The results from the HTTP request

return.description:
The "body" property of the result, conditionally augmented with
                 pagination information if the result is a partial collection.

classitems.description: Extract and return the headers property from a superagent response object

params.name: result
params.description: The results from the HTTP request

return.description: The "headers" property of the result

classitems.description:
Process arrays of taxonomy terms into query parameters.
All terms listed in the arrays will be required (AND behavior).

This method will not be called with any values unless we are handling
an endpoint with the filter mixin; however, since parameter handling
(and therefore `_renderQuery()`) are part of WPRequest itself, this
helper method lives here alongside the code where it is used.

params.name: taxonomyFilters
params.description: An object of taxonomy term arrays, keyed by taxonomy name

return.description: An object of prepareFilters-ready query arg and query param value pairs

classitems.description:
Return an object with any properties with undefined, null or empty string
values removed.

params.name: obj
params.description: An object of key/value pairs

return.description: That object with all empty values removed

classitems.description:
Assert whether a provided URL component is "valid" by checking it against
an array of registered path component validator methods for that level of
the URL path.

params.name: levelDefinitions
params.description: An array of Level Definition objects

params.name: levelContents
params.description:
The URL path string that has been specified
                                   for use on the provided level

return.description:
Whether the provided input matches any of the provided
level validation functions

classitems.description:
Combine the API endpoint root URI and link URI into a valid request URL.
Endpoints are generally a full path to the JSON API's root endpoint, such
as `website.com/wp-json`: the link headers, however, are returned as root-
relative paths. Concatenating these would generate a URL such as
`website.com/wp-json/wp-json/posts?page=2`: we must intelligently merge the
URI strings in order to generate a valid new request URL.

params.name: endpoint
params.description: The endpoint URL for the REST API root

params.name: linkPath
params.description: A root-relative link path to an API request

return.description: The full URL path to the provided link

classitems.description:
If the response is not paged, return the body as-is. If pagination
information is present in the response headers, parse those headers into
a custom `_paging` property on the response body. `_paging` contains links
to the previous and next pages in the collection, as well as metadata
about the size and number of pages in the collection.

The structure of the `_paging` property is as follows:

- `total` {Integer} The total number of records in the collection
- `totalPages` {Integer} The number of pages available
- `links` {Object} The parsed "links" headers, separated into individual URI strings
- `next` {WPRequest} A WPRequest object bound to the "next" page (if page exists)
- `prev` {WPRequest} A WPRequest object bound to the "previous" page (if page exists)

params.name: result
params.description: The response object from the HTTP request

params.name: endpoint
params.description: The base URL of the requested API endpoint

return.description:
The body of the HTTP request, conditionally augmented with
                  pagination metadata

classitems.description:
Process the endpoint query's filter objects into a valid query string.
Nested objects and Array properties are rendered with indexed array syntax.
example:
_renderQuery({ p1: 'val1', p2: 'val2' });  // ?p1=val1&p2=val2
    _renderQuery({ obj: { prop: 'val' } });    // ?obj[prop]=val
    _renderQuery({ arr: [ 'val1', 'val2' ] }); // ?arr[0]=val1&arr[1]=val2
classitems.name: _renderQuery

return.description: A query string representing the specified filter parameters

classitems.description:
Set a component of the resource URL itself (as opposed to a query parameter)

If a path component has already been set at this level, throw an error:
requests are meant to be transient, so any re-writing of a previously-set
path part value is likely to be a mistake.
classitems.name: setPathPart

params.name: level
params.description: A "level" of the path to set, e.g. "1" or "2"

params.name: val
params.description: The value to set at that path part level

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Validate whether the specified path parts are valid for this endpoint

"Path parts" are non-query-string URL segments, like "some" "path" in the URL
`mydomain.com/some/path?and=a&query=string&too`. Because a well-formed path
is necessary to execute a successful API request, we throw an error if the
user has omitted a value (such as `/some/[missing component]/url`) or has
provided a path part value that does not match the regular expression the
API uses to goven that segment.
classitems.name: validatePath

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining), if no errors were found

classitems.description: Set a parameter to render into the final query URI.
classitems.name: param

params.name: props
params.description:
The name of the parameter to set, or an object containing
                             parameter keys and their corresponding values

params.name: value
params.description: The value of the parameter being set

params.name: merge
params.description: Whether to merge the value (true) or replace it (false, default)

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Set the context of the request. Used primarily to expose private values on a request
object, by setting the context to "edit".
classitems.name: context

params.name: context
params.description: The context to set on the request

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Convenience wrapper for `.context( 'edit' )`

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Return embedded resources as part of the response payload.
classitems.name: embed

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining)

classitems.name: _checkMethodSupport

params.name: method
params.description: An HTTP method to check ('get', 'post', etc)

return.description: true iff the method is within this._supportedMethods

classitems.description: Validate & assemble a path string from the request object's _path

return.description: The rendered path

classitems.description:
Set the namespace of the request, e.g. to specify the API root for routes
registered by wp core v2 ("wp/v2") or by any given plugin. Any previously-
set namespace will be overwritten by subsequent calls to the method.
classitems.name: namespace

params.name: namespace
params.description: A namespace string, e.g. "wp/v2"

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Set a request to use authentication, and optionally provide auth credentials

Note: the `.auth( username, password )` signature is _deprecated_, use an object
with username and password properties instead as in the below example.

If auth credentials were already specified when the WP instance was created, calling
`.auth` on the request chain will set that request to use the existing credentials:
example:
use existing credentials

    request.auth().get...

Alternatively, a username & password (or nonce) can be explicitly passed into `.auth`:
classitems.name: auth

params.name: credentials
params.description:
An object with 'username' and 'password' string
                                       properties, or else a 'nonce' property

props.name: username
props.description: A WP-API Basic HTTP Authentication username

props.name: password
props.description: A WP-API Basic HTTP Authentication password

props.name: nonce
props.description: A WP nonce for use with cookie authentication

return.description: The WPRequest instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Specify a file or a file buffer to attach to the request, for use when
creating a new Media item
example:
within a server context

    wp.media()
      // Pass .file() the file system path to a file to upload
      .file( '/path/to/file.jpg' )
      .create({})...

within a browser context

    wp.media()
      // Pass .file() the file reference from an HTML file input
      .file( document.querySelector( 'input[type="file"]' ).files[0] )
      .create({})...
classitems.name: file

params.name: file
params.description:
A path to a file (in Node) or an file object
                              (Node or Browser) to attach to the request

params.name: name
params.description: An (optional) filename to use for the file

return.description: [description]

params.name: callback
params.description: A callback to invoke with the results of the GET request

return.description: A promise to the results of the HTTP request

classitems.description:
To avoid requiring that auto-discovery be utilized every time the API client
is initialized, this library ships with a built-in route definition from a
vanilla WordPress REST API installation. That file may be updated by
installing the API plugin on a clean WP development instance, with no other
plugins running, and downloading the JSON output from `yourwpsite.com/wp-json/`
into the "endpoint-response.json" file in this directory.

That file can also be generated by running this script against the same live
WP REST API instance to download that same file, the difference being that,
if the `endpoint-response.json` file is downloaded through this script, it
will be run through the `simplifyObject` utility to cut out about 1/3 of the
bytes of the response by removing properties that do not effect route generation.

This script is NOT intended to be a dependency of any part of wp.js, and is
provided purely as a utility for upgrading the built-in copy of the endpoint
response JSON file that is used to bootstrap the default route handlers.
example:
# Invoke directly, run against default endpoint (details below)
    ./generate-endpoint-response-json.js

    # Invoke with `node` CLI, run against default endpoint
    node ./generate-endpoint-response-json --endpoint=http://my-site.com/wp-json

This script runs against http://wpapi.loc/wp-json by default, but it can be
run against an arbitrary WordPress REST API endpoint by passing the --endpoint
argument on the CLI:

# Invoke directly, run against an arbitrary WordPress API root
    ./generate-endpoint-response-json.js --endpoint=http://my-site.com/wp-json

    # Invoke with `node` CLI, run against an arbitrary WordPress API root
    node ./generate-endpoint-response-json --endpoint=http://my-site.com/wp-json

Either form will update the `endpoint-response.json` file in this directory,
providing that the endpoint data is downloaded successfully.

This script also has some utility for downloading a custom JSON file for your
own WP REST API-enabled site, so that you can bootstrap your own routes without
incurring an HTTP request. To output to a different directory than the default
(which is this directory, `lib/data/`), pass an --output argument on the CLI:

# Output to your current working directory
    ./path/to/this/dir/generate-endpoint-response-json.js --output=.

    # Output to an arbitrary absolute path
    ./path/to/this/dir/generate-endpoint-response-json.js --output=/home/mordor/output.json

These command-line flags may be combined, and you will usually want to use
--endpoint alongside --output to download your own JSON into your own directory.

classitems.description:
Walk through the keys and values of a provided object, removing any properties
which would be inessential to the generation of the route tree used to deduce
route handlers from a `wp-json/` root API endpoint. This module is not used by
the wpapi module itself, but is rather a dependency of the script that is used
to create the `endpoint-response.json` file that is shipped along with this
module for use in generating the "default" routes.

params.name: obj
params.description: An arbitrary JS value, probably an object

return.description:
The passed-in value, with non-essential args properties and all
_links properties removes.

classitems.description:
Specify key-value pairs by which to filter the API results (commonly used
to retrieve only posts meeting certain criteria, such as posts within a
particular category or by a particular author).
classitems.name: filter

params.name: props
params.description: A filter property name string, or object of name/value pairs

params.name: value
params.description: The value(s) corresponding to the provided filter property

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Restrict the query results to posts matching one or more taxonomy terms.

params.name: taxonomy
params.description: The name of the taxonomy to filter by

params.name: term
params.description: A string or integer, or array thereof, representing terms

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.name: category

params.name: category
params.description: A string or integer, or array thereof, representing terms

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.name: tag

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Query for posts published in a given year.
classitems.name: year

params.name: year
params.description: integer representation of year requested

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

Query for posts published in a given month, either by providing the number
of the requested month (e.g. 3), or the month's name as a string (e.g. "March")
classitems.name: month

params.name: month
params.description: Integer for month (1) or month string ("January")

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Add the day filter into the request to retrieve posts for a given day

params.name: day
params.description: Integer representation of the day requested

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Specify that we are requesting a page by its path (specific to Page resources)
classitems.name: path

params.name: path
params.description: The root-relative URL path for a page

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
This module defines a mapping between supported GET request query parameter
arguments and their corresponding mixin, if available.

Set the pagination of a request. Use in conjunction with `.perPage()` for explicit
pagination handling. (The number of pages in a response can be retrieved from the
response's `_paging.totalPages` property.)
classitems.name: page

params.name: pageNumber
params.description: The page number of results to retrieve

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Set the number of items to be returned in a page of responses.
classitems.name: perPage

params.name: itemsPerPage
params.description: The number of items to return in one page of results

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Query a collection for members with a specific slug.
classitems.name: slug

params.name: slug
params.description: A post slug (slug), e.g. "hello-world"

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Alias for .slug()
classitems.name: name

params.name: slug
params.description: A post name (slug), e.g. "hello-world"

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Filter results to those matching the specified search terms.
classitems.name: search

params.name: searchString
params.description: A string to search for within post content

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Query for posts by a specific author.
This method will replace any previous 'author' query parameters that had been set.

Note that this method will either set the "author" top-level query parameter,
or else the "author_name" filter parameter: this is irregular as most parameter
helper methods either set a top level parameter or a filter, not both.
classitems.name: author

params.name: author
params.description: The nicename or ID for a particular author

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Search for hierarchical taxonomy terms that are children of the parent term
indicated by the provided term ID
classitems.name: parent

params.name: parentId
params.description: The ID of a (hierarchical) taxonomy term

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Specify the post for which to retrieve terms (relevant for *e.g.* taxonomy
and comment collection endpoints). `forPost` is used to avoid conflicting
with the `.post()` method, which corresponds to the HTTP POST action.
classitems.name: forPost

params.name: post
params.description: The ID of the post for which to retrieve terms

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Retrieve only records published before a specified date
example:
Provide an ISO 8601-compliant date string

    wp.posts().before('2016-03-22')...

Provide a JavaScript Date object

    wp.posts().before( new Date( 2016, 03, 22 ) )...
classitems.name: before

params.name: date
params.description: An ISO 8601-compliant date string, or Date object

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Retrieve only records published after a specified date
example:
Provide an ISO 8601-compliant date string

    wp.posts().after('1986-03-22')...

Provide a JavaScript Date object

    wp.posts().after( new Date( 1986, 03, 22 ) )...
classitems.name: after

params.name: date
params.description: An ISO 8601-compliant date string, or Date object

return.description: The request instance (for chaining)

classitems.description: Utility function for sorting arrays of numbers or strings.

params.name: a
params.description: The first comparator operand

params.name: a
params.description: The second comparator operand

return.description: -1 if the values are backwards, 1 if they're ordered, and 0 if they're the same

classitems.description:
Regular Expression to identify a capture group in PCRE formats
`(?<name>regex)`, `(?'name'regex)` or `(?P<name>regex)` (see
regular-expressions.info/refext.html); RegExp is built as a string
to enable more detailed annotation.

Fetch the headers for a URL and inspect them to attempt to locate an API
endpoint header. Return a promise that will be resolved with a string, or
rejected if no such header can be located.

params.name: url
params.description: An arbitrary URL within an API-enabled WordPress site

params.name: useGET
params.description:
Whether to use GET or HEAD to read the URL, to enable
                          the method to upgrade to a full GET request if a HEAD
                          request initially fails.

return.description: A promise to the string containing the API endpoint URL

classitems.description: Function to be called with the API url, once we have found one

params.name: linkUrl
params.description: The href of the <link> pointing to the API root

return.description: Promise that resolves once the API root has been inspected

classitems.description:
Given an array of route definitions and a specific namespace for those routes,
recurse through the node tree representing all possible routes within the
provided namespace to define path value setters (and corresponding property
validators) for all possible variants of each resource's API endpoints.

params.name: namespace
params.description: The namespace string for these routes

params.name: routesByNamespace
params.description:
A dictionary of namespace - route definition
                                  object pairs as generated from buildRouteTree,
                                  where each route definition object is a dictionary
                                  keyed by route definition strings

return.description: A dictionary of endpoint request handler factories

classitems.description:
Semi-private instance property specifying the available URL path options
for this endpoint request handler, keyed by ascending whole numbers.
classitems.name: _levels

classitems.description:
Return a function to set part of the request URL path.

Path part setter methods may be either dynamic (*i.e.* may represent a
"named group") or non-dynamic (representing a static part of the URL, which
is usually a collection endpoint of some sort). Which type of function is
returned depends on whether a given route has one or many sub-resources.

params.name: node
params.description: [description]

return.description: [description]

classitems.description: Set a dymanic (named-group) path part of a query URL.
example:
// id() is a dynamic path part setter:
    wp.posts().id( 7 ); // Get posts/7

params.name: val
params.description: The path part value to set

return.description: The handler instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Set a non-dymanic (non-named-group) path part of a query URL, and
set the value of a subresource if an input value is provided and
exactly one named-group child node exists.

params.name: val
params.description:
The path part value to set (if provided)
                              for a subresource within this resource

return.description: The handler instance (for chaining)

classitems.description:
Walk the tree of a specific resource node to create the setter methods

The API we want to produce from the node tree looks like this:

    wp.posts();                        /wp/v2/posts
    wp.posts().id( 7 );                /wp/v2/posts/7
    wp.posts().id( 7 ).revisions();    /wp/v2/posts/7/revisions
    wp.posts().id( 7 ).revisions( 8 ); /wp/v2/posts/7/revisions/8

^ That last one's the tricky one: we can deduce that this parameter is "id", but
that param will already be taken by the post ID, so sub-collections have to be
set up as `.revisions()` to get the collection, and `.revisions( id )` to get a
specific resource.

params.name: node
params.description: A node object

props.name: children
props.description:
An object of child nodes
// @return {isLeaf} A boolean indicating whether the processed node is a leaf

classitems.description: Create a node handler specification object from a route definition object

params.name: routeDefinition
params.description: A route definition object

params.name: resource
params.description: The string key of the resource for which to create a handler

return.description: A handler spec object with _path, _levels and _setters properties

classitems.description: Method to use when reducing route components array.
classitems.name: _reduceRouteComponents

params.name: routeObj
params.description: A route definition object (set via .bind partial application)

params.name: topLevel
params.description:
The top-level route tree object for this set of routes (set
                             via .bind partial application)

params.name: parentLevel
params.description:
The memo object, which is mutated as the reducer adds
                             a new level handler for each level in the route

params.name: component
params.description: The string defining this route component

params.name: idx
params.description: The index of this component within the components array

params.name: components
params.description: The array of all components

return.description: The child object of the level being reduced

params.name: namespaces
params.description:
The memo object that becomes a dictionary mapping API
                              namespaces to an object of the namespace's routes

params.name: routeObj
params.description: A route definition object

params.name: route
params.description: The string key of the `routeObj` route object

return.description: The namespaces dictionary memo object

classitems.description:
Build a route tree by reducing over a routes definition object from the API
root endpoint response object

params.name: routes
params.description: A dictionary of routes keyed by route regex strings

return.description:
A dictionary, keyed by namespace, of resource handler
factory methods for each namespace's resources

classitems.description:
This is a curry-able pluck function, that is all. Inspecting a collection of
human-readable strings is usually a more comprehensible way to validate the
right results were returned than using arbitrary values.
example:
Pluck the slugs titles from a collection of terms

    var slugs = getProp( collection, 'slug' );

params.name: property
params.description: The name of the property to pluck

params.name: collection
params.description: An array of response objects whence to pluck

return.description: The values of that property from each collection member

classitems.description:
This method is a super-pluck capable of grabbing the rendered version of
a nested property on a WP API response object. Inspecting a collection of
human-readable properties is usually a more comprehensible way to validate
that the right results were returned than using IDs or arbitrary values.
example:
Pluck the rendered titles from the post

    var titles = getRenderedProp( collection, 'title' );

params.name: property
params.description: The name of the rendered property to pluck

params.name: collection
params.description: An array of response objects whence to pluck

return.description:
The collection of values for the rendered variants of
the specified response object property

classitems.description:
The Gruntfile in this project is not responsible for the code build or
linting, and instead handles all tasks related to documentation generation
and output.
Convenience method for making a new WP instance
example:
These are equivalent:

    var wp = new WP({ endpoint: 'http://my.blog.url/wp-json' });
    var wp = WP.site( 'http://my.blog.url/wp-json' );

`WP.site` can take an optional API root response JSON object to use when
bootstrapping the client's endpoint handler methods: if no second parameter
is provided, the client instance is assumed to be using the default API
with no additional plugins and is initialized with handlers for only those
default API routes.
classitems.name: site

params.name: endpoint
params.description: The URI for a WP-API endpoint

params.name: routes
params.description:
The "routes" object from the JSON object returned
                         from the root API endpoint of a WP site, which should
                         be a dictionary of route definition objects keyed by
                         the route's regex pattern

return.description: A new WP instance, bound to the provided endpoint

classitems.description:
Generate a request against a completely arbitrary endpoint, with no assumptions about
or mutation of path, filtering, or query parameters. This request is not restricted to
the endpoint specified during WP object instantiation.
example:
Generate a request to the explicit URL "http://your.website.com/wp-json/some/custom/path"

    wp.url( 'http://your.website.com/wp-json/some/custom/path' ).get()...
classitems.name: url

params.name: url
params.description: The URL to request

return.description: A WPRequest object bound to the provided URL

classitems.description:
Generate a query against an arbitrary path on the current endpoint. This is useful for
requesting resources at custom WP-API endpoints, such as WooCommerce's `/products`.
classitems.name: root

params.name: relativePath
params.description: An endpoint-relative path to which to bind the request

return.description: A request object

classitems.description:
Set the authentication to use for a WP site handler instance. Accepts basic
HTTP authentication credentials (string username & password) or a Nonce (for
cookie authentication) by default; may be overloaded to accept OAuth credentials
in the future.
classitems.name: auth

params.name: credentials
params.description: An authentication credentials object

props.name: username
props.description: A WP-API Basic HTTP Authentication username

props.name: password
props.description: A WP-API Basic HTTP Authentication password

props.name: nonce
props.description: A WP nonce for use with cookie authentication

return.description: The WP site handler instance, for chaining

classitems.description:
Deduce request methods from a provided API root JSON response object's
routes dictionary, and assign those methods to the current instance. If
no routes dictionary is provided then the instance will be bootstrapped
with route handlers for the default API endpoints only.

This method is called automatically during WP instance creation.
classitems.name: bootstrap

params.name: routes
params.description:
The "routes" object from the JSON object returned
                       from the root API endpoint of a WP site, which should
                       be a dictionary of route definition objects keyed by
                       the route's regex pattern

return.description: The bootstrapped WP client instance (for chaining or assignment)

classitems.description: Access API endpoint handlers from a particular API namespace object

params.name: namespace
params.description: A namespace string

return.description:
An object of route endpoint handler methods for the
routes within the specified namespace

classitems.description:
Take an arbitrary WordPress site, deduce the WP REST API root endpoint, query
that endpoint, and parse the response JSON. Use the returned JSON response
to instantiate a WP instance bound to the provided site.
classitems.name: discover

params.name: url
params.description: A URL within a WP endpoint

return.description:
A promise that resolves to a configured WP instance bound
to the deduced endpoint, or rejected if an endpoint is not found or the
library is unable to parse the provided endpoint.

return a promise that will resolve or reject when the subprocess completes

then executes those functions sequentially to execute each action
Missing item type

Missing item type
Submit the provided superagent request object, invoke a callback (if it was
provided), and return a promise to the response from the HTTP request.

Missing item type
Extract and return the headers property from a superagent response object

Missing item type
Process arrays of taxonomy terms into query parameters.
All terms listed in the arrays will be required (AND behavior).

This method will not be called with any values unless we are handling
an endpoint with the filter mixin; however, since parameter handling
(and therefore `_renderQuery()`) are part of WPRequest itself, this
helper method lives here alongside the code where it is used.

Missing item type
Return an object with any properties with undefined, null or empty string
values removed.

Missing item type
Assert whether a provided URL component is "valid" by checking it against
an array of registered path component validator methods for that level of
the URL path.

Missing item type
Combine the API endpoint root URI and link URI into a valid request URL.
Endpoints are generally a full path to the JSON API's root endpoint, such
as `website.com/wp-json`: the link headers, however, are returned as root-
relative paths. Concatenating these would generate a URL such as
`website.com/wp-json/wp-json/posts?page=2`: we must intelligently merge the
URI strings in order to generate a valid new request URL.

Missing item type
If the response is not paged, return the body as-is. If pagination
information is present in the response headers, parse those headers into
a custom `_paging` property on the response body. `_paging` contains links
to the previous and next pages in the collection, as well as metadata
about the size and number of pages in the collection.

The structure of the `_paging` property is as follows:

- `total` {Integer} The total number of records in the collection
- `totalPages` {Integer} The number of pages available
- `links` {Object} The parsed "links" headers, separated into individual URI strings
- `next` {WPRequest} A WPRequest object bound to the "next" page (if page exists)
- `prev` {WPRequest} A WPRequest object bound to the "previous" page (if page exists)
Missing item type
Missing item type
Missing item type

Missing item type
To avoid requiring that auto-discovery be utilized every time the API client
is initialized, this library ships with a built-in route definition from a
vanilla WordPress REST API installation. That file may be updated by
installing the API plugin on a clean WP development instance, with no other
plugins running, and downloading the JSON output from `yourwpsite.com/wp-json/`
into the "endpoint-response.json" file in this directory.

That file can also be generated by running this script against the same live
WP REST API instance to download that same file, the difference being that,
if the `endpoint-response.json` file is downloaded through this script, it
will be run through the `simplifyObject` utility to cut out about 1/3 of the
bytes of the response by removing properties that do not effect route generation.

This script is NOT intended to be a dependency of any part of wp.js, and is
provided purely as a utility for upgrading the built-in copy of the endpoint
response JSON file that is used to bootstrap the default route handlers.

Missing item type
Walk through the keys and values of a provided object, removing any properties
which would be inessential to the generation of the route tree used to deduce
route handlers from a `wp-json/` root API endpoint. This module is not used by
the wpapi module itself, but is rather a dependency of the script that is used
to create the `endpoint-response.json` file that is shipped along with this
module for use in generating the "default" routes.

Missing item type
This module defines a mapping between supported GET request query parameter
arguments and their corresponding mixin, if available.

Missing item type
Utility function for sorting arrays of numbers or strings.

Missing item type
Regular Expression to identify a capture group in PCRE formats
`(?<name>regex)`, `(?'name'regex)` or `(?P<name>regex)` (see
regular-expressions.info/refext.html); RegExp is built as a string
to enable more detailed annotation.

Missing item type
Fetch the headers for a URL and inspect them to attempt to locate an API
endpoint header. Return a promise that will be resolved with a string, or
rejected if no such header can be located.

Missing item type
Function to be called with the API url, once we have found one

Missing item type
Given an array of route definitions and a specific namespace for those routes,
recurse through the node tree representing all possible routes within the
provided namespace to define path value setters (and corresponding property
validators) for all possible variants of each resource's API endpoints.

Missing item type
Return a function to set part of the request URL path.

Path part setter methods may be either dynamic (*i.e.* may represent a
"named group") or non-dynamic (representing a static part of the URL, which
is usually a collection endpoint of some sort). Which type of function is
returned depends on whether a given route has one or many sub-resources.

Missing item type
Set a dymanic (named-group) path part of a query URL.

Missing item type
Set a non-dymanic (non-named-group) path part of a query URL, and
set the value of a subresource if an input value is provided and
exactly one named-group child node exists.

Missing item type
Walk the tree of a specific resource node to create the setter methods

The API we want to produce from the node tree looks like this:

    wp.posts();                        /wp/v2/posts
    wp.posts().id( 7 );                /wp/v2/posts/7
    wp.posts().id( 7 ).revisions();    /wp/v2/posts/7/revisions
    wp.posts().id( 7 ).revisions( 8 ); /wp/v2/posts/7/revisions/8

^ That last one's the tricky one: we can deduce that this parameter is "id", but
that param will already be taken by the post ID, so sub-collections have to be
set up as `.revisions()` to get the collection, and `.revisions( id )` to get a
specific resource.
